awd_titl_txt: Conference: Scientific Evidence in the Courts: The Sciences' Role in the Promotion of Justice
awd_abstract_narration:
In 1923, the District of Columbia Court ruled that judges have a constitutional responsibility to assess the reliability of scientific and technical evidence and expert witness testimony (Frye v. United States), establishing guidelines for judges to determine what evidence and whose testimony will be presented at trial or provided to the jury for their consideration. Since this ruling, the Supreme Court of the United States and Congress have expanded upon and articulated further guidance for this gatekeeping function (the Federal Rules of Evidence, 1975; Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 1993; General Electric Co. v. Joiner, 1997; and Kumho Tire Co. v. Carmichael, 1999). However, the applications of the Frye and Daubert Standards remain inconsistent across both federal and state courts, allowing for unreliable evidence and testimony to enter trials, increasing the likelihood of unjust outcomes, such as wrongful convictions, as well as other violations of constitutional rights. Some experts suggest that the adoption of the Daubert Standard has also constrained access to the justice system for litigants from historically marginalized populations, specifically African Americans. This conference will reflect upon the current body of research regarding the courts’ application of admissibility standards and explore the potential challenges to these standards arising from quickly developing scientific fields such as artificial intelligence, climate science, statistical modeling, and advances in forensic science. Event speakers and attendees will assess current practices and identify pathways for improving the use of credible, trustworthy scientific evidence and expert witness testimony by federal and state courts going forward.

The conference in Washington, DC, will be an efficient and effective method of assembling a strategically identified and diverse group of people from across research disciplines, societal sectors, and geography, to share and discuss relevant knowledge and its impacts on society at large. The event will bring together members of both the scientific and legal communities, with government officials, academics, and representatives of nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) dedicated to improving the United States justice system. The research that will be presented and discussed in the conference, and the needs for future research that will be identified, are directly related to improving the judicial system’s accurate and effective use of scientific evidence and to building public trust in the judiciary.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), in collaboration with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM), convened a two-day conference in September 2023 to examine critical issues regarding scientific and technical evidence in United States courts. The conference took place at AAAS headquarters in Washington, DC, and was timed to mark the anniversaries of two key U.S. federal court opinions outlining the role of judges as “gatekeepers” with the responsibility of evaluating scientific evidence before it is admitted in litigation: Frye v. United States (1923) and Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (1993).

The conference brought together members of the scientific and legal communities with government officials, advocates from NGOs dedicated to improving the U.S. justice system, and individuals who were wrongfully convicted of crimes they did not commit. The conference was also made available to universities and several hosted "watch parties" for faculty and students. 

The research that was presented and discussed in the conference, and the needs for future research that were identified, are directly related to improving the judicial system’s accurate and effective use of scientific evidence and building public trust in the judiciary. The specific themes addressed are vital to national justice priorities. Organizing committee members were invited, in part, because of their leadership positions within these respective professional spheres and for their dedication to cross-sector communication and collaboration. By involving stakeholders in the conference as panelists and participants, the conference conveyed current research findings directly to those best placed to apply them in the justice system. Stakeholder engagement with the scientists who are conducting relevant research also helped to identify further research priorities. That, in turn, is anticipated to have additional positive impacts on future judicial decisions.

Over two days with 16 sessions, the 52 speakers, panelists, and moderators reflected on the history of scientific evidence in the courts. The diverse participants from across research disciplines and societal sectors – at least 209 people in-person and online from across the U.S. – identified key evidentiary issues in forensic science, psychology, neuroscience, statistics, environmental science, computer science, and genetics. They highlighted the very serious consequences when there are errors, omissions, or misunderstandings, including wrongful conviction.

Presenters also identified several innovative approaches aimed at better aligning scientific and legal fact-finding methods. For example, one session explored in depth the ways in which the prosecution integrity unit in Houston, Texas has improved accountability in forensic sciences in that jurisdiction. Other courts are appointing special magistrates for scientific evidence, experimenting with expert roundtables, or turning to independent court-appointed scientific experts. Another innovation at the state level, "changed science" laws, allows new scientific findings as the basis for appealing criminal conviction. These and other reforms discussed require further study to determine their efficacy.  

In other sessions, researchers shared their findings from neuroscience, psychology, and statistics about how judges and jurors learn complex, technical information and apply it to make decisions. Participants also discussed opportunities and limitations of emerging technologies and new interdisciplinary methods, such as genetic genealogy, as investigative tools.

These presentations and the open, cross-sector discussions throughout the conference identified priorities for future collaboration and research among the legal community and scientific researchers who have an interest in how science is used in legal proceedings. For instance, to make progress on leveraging improvements in science to help incarcerated persons overturn convictions based on questionable or misunderstood evidence, it would first be beneficial to “landscape” the status of states’ laws, statutes of limitation, and rules of evidence. Efforts are also needed to enhance the ways in which scientific information is conveyed in legal contexts. There was consensus that these next steps will require ongoing communication and collaboration, moving some to suggest a community of practice and future conferences like this one. 

All conference keynotes, panels, and roundtables were recorded and are publicly available on the AAAS website and the AAAS YouTube channel.
